com.nitrous.gwt.earth.client.api
Class KmlScreenOverlay

java.lang.Object
  com.google.gwt.core.client.JavaScriptObject
      com.nitrous.gwt.earth.client.api.GESchemaObject
          com.nitrous.gwt.earth.client.api.GEEventEmitter
              com.nitrous.gwt.earth.client.api.KmlObject
                  com.nitrous.gwt.earth.client.api.KmlFeature
                      com.nitrous.gwt.earth.client.api.KmlOverlay
                          com.nitrous.gwt.earth.client.api.KmlScreenOverlay

public class KmlScreenOverlay
extends KmlOverlay

Draws an image overlay fixed to the screen. Sample uses for ScreenOverlays are compasses, logos, and heads-up displays. ScreenOverlay sizing is determined by the size element. Positioning of the overlay is handled by mapping a point in the image specified by screenXY to a point on the screen specified by overlayXY. Then the image is rotated by rotation degrees about a point relative to the screen specified by rotationXY. Note: screenXY and overlayXY behave opposite to their corresponding behaviors in KML. This is due to a bug in the Earth API that will intentionally remain unfixed until a major version change.

Author:
Nick

Constructor Detail

KmlScreenOverlay

protected KmlScreenOverlay()
Method Detail

getScreenXY

public final KmlVec2 getScreenXY()
Specifies a point on (or outside of) the overlay image that is mapped to the screen coordinate. It requires x and y values, and the units for those values.
Note: screenXY and overlayXY behave opposite to their corresponding behaviors in KML. This is due to a bug in the Earth API that will intentionally remain unfixed until a major version change.

Returns:

getOverlayXY

public final KmlVec2 getOverlayXY()
Specifies a point relative to the screen origin that the overlay image is mapped to. The x and y values can be specified in three different ways: as pixels ("pixels"), as fractions of the screen ("fraction"), or as inset pixels ("insetPixels"), which is an offset in pixels from the upper right corner of the screen. The x and y positions can be specified in different ways - for example, x can be in pixels and y can be a fraction. The origin of the coordinate system is in the lower left corner of the screen. Note: screenXY and overlayXY behave opposite to their corresponding behaviors in KML. This is due to a bug in the Earth API that will intentionally remain unfixed until a major version change.

Returns:

getRotationXY

public final KmlVec2 getRotationXY()
Returns:
Point relative to the screen about which the screen overlay is rotated.

getSize

public final KmlVec2 getSize()
Specifies the size of the image for the screen overlay, as follows 
 
  • A value of -1 indicates to use the native dimension
    • 
 
  • A value of 0 indicates to maintain the aspect ratio
    • 
 
  • A value of n sets the value of the dimension
    •

    Returns:

    getRotation

    public final double getRotation()
    Returns:
    Adjusts how the image is placed inside the field of view. This element is useful if your image has been rotated and deviates slightly from a desired horizontal view.

    setRotation

    public final void setRotation(double rotation)
    Parameters:
    rotation - Adjusts how the image is placed inside the field of view. This element is useful if your image has been rotated and deviates slightly from a desired horizontal view.
